_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Petal Facility RMP Executive Summary


Enterprise Products Operating L.P. - Petal Facility
Hwy 11 N.
Petal, Mississippi 39465

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Enterprise is committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

?    A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation
?    An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
?    A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
?    An overview of our emergency response program
?    An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public and the environment.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Our production facility has produced propane (C3), isobutane (iC4), and normal butane (nC4), which contain minute amounts "heavier" components often referred to as natural gasolines (C5 & C6).  The facility is a fractionator that uses a feedstock known as commercial butane.  The Petal fractionator is a natural gas liquids processing facility, which fractionates the commercial butane into propane, isobutane and normal butane.  Since the last reporting period, the fractionator facility has been decommissioned.  It has been deinventoried of hydrocarbons, placed under an inert (nitrogen) environment, and is isolated from the remainder of the facility.

The storage tanks associated with this facility remain in service.  These tanks contain the following chemicals that the EPA has ide

ntified as having the potential to cause significant off site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics

No toxic chemicals are located on this site.

Flammables

Propane is no longer a finished product at the Petal facility but rather a commodity that is transferred via pipelines, railcar, transport truck and product tanks that are incidental to support the pipelines and rail/truck terminal.  The quantity of the product is distributed throughout the complex.  The largest portions of the product are in an underground storage well (220,000,000 lbs.), a service vessel (125,000 lbs.) and three product tanks (totaling 375,000 lbs.).  

Butane (normal butane) is no longer a finished product at the Petal facility but rather a commodity that is transferred via pipelines, railcar, transport truck and product tanks that are incidental to support the pipelines and rail/truck terminal.  The quantity of the product is distributed throughout the complex.  The largest portion of the product is in an underground storage well (247,000,000 lbs.), a service vessel (125,000 lbs.) and three product tanks (totaling 375,000 lbs.).  

Isobutane is no longer a finished product at the Petal facility but rather a commodity that is transferred via pipelines, railcar, transport truck and product tanks that are incidental to support the pipelines and rail/truck terminal.  The quantity of the product is distributed throughout the complex.  The largest portions of the product are in an underground storage well (158,000,000 lbs.), a service vessel (125,000 lbs.) and three product tanks (totaling 375,000 lbs.).

The DePropanizer fractionator tower, which contained an inventory of 10,800 lbs., has been decommissioned and isolated from any known process and is under a nitrogen blanket.   The associated DeButanizer and DeIsobutanizer towers, which contained a mixed inventory of butane and isobutane (66,100 lbs.), has also been decommissioned and is isolated from any known

process and is under a nitrogen blanket.  Therefore, the previously reported inventory of on site propane, butane, isobutene and gasoline has decreased by 66,100 lbs.

The plant product tanks are all that remain in service and at the present time contain dry propane.  These tanks now support the Underground Storage and Product Handling Terminal.

Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that are posed to our employees, the public and the environment by our use of these chemicals.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program
And Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Enterprise takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:

Process Safety Information    Process Hazard Analysis    Operating Procedures
Training    Mechanical Integrity    Management of Change
Pre-Startup Safety Review    Compliance Audits    Incident Investigation
Employee Participation    Hot Work Permits    Management of Contractors

As part of our prevention efforts, we have multiple programs in which our employees participate.  We have a training program in which the Operations/Maintenance personnel are specifically trained in the operations of the plant, the operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and specific other regulations and policies as well as training in all areas of emergency response.  We train, use and apply the guidelines of our Process Safety Management (PSM) program, which include all of the above listed areas.

The Operations personnel make regular walk-through inspections of the equipment and process they operate.  If anything out of the ordinary is found, it is resolved by the observer or is reported to the local management in order to expediently resolve any problems.

These individual elements of our prevention program work together to help prevent accidental chemical re

leases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standards that these management systems set.  The way we do business, with specific accountabilities and controls in place ensure that we are meeting our own high goals for accident prevention.

Five Year Accident History

We keep records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  There have not been any reportable releases, which involved any type of accidental releases involving material covered under the EPA's RMP rule, during the past five years at this facility.

If there is a reportable incident, Enterprise will conduct a formal incident investigation(s) to identify and correct the root causes of the event(s).

Emergency Response Program

Enterprise maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting our employees, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our plan with the Petal Dome Mutual Aid as well as the community emergency response organization.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The following lists actions that we have completed or are planning to implement at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

?    We are consistently reviewing and improving our PSM Program.  The program has recently been reviewed and written management systems have been updated and strengthened.
?    We incorporated an electronic system that organizes, tracks and files all of the management of change projects.
?    The mechanical integrity program is presently being reviewed and updated.
?    The Safety Procedures are periodically reviewed and updated.
?    We plan to conduct safety inspections of the operating process units as well as continue to conduct PSM audits.
